Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance providing for a retirement plan for town officers and employees saved from repeal, § 1-11(4). 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 2-61. - Established. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of G.S. § 7-450, there shall be established in the town a retirement system for officers and employees and their beneficiaries. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 1, 1-22-79) 
Sec. 2-62. - Governed by pension plan adopted by town council. 
    The retirement system for officers and employees and their beneficiaries shall be governed by the terms and conditions of the pension plan that the pension and retirement committee of the town recommends to the town council, and which plan has been approved and adopted by the town council. The town council reserves the right to amend such plan from time to time as it deems in the best interest of officers and employees of the town and their beneficiaries. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 8, 1-22-79) 
Secs. 2-63-2-85. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Pension and Retirement Committee[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-146 et seq. 

Sec. 2-86. - Creation; appointment; composition; compensation; vacancies. 
    There is created in the town a pension and retirement committee, to be appointed by the town council, of not less than three members, nor more than five members, to administer the pension plan of the town. Members of the pension and retirement committee shall serve without pay or other remuneration, at the town council's pleasure. Vacancies shall be filled by the town council. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 2, 1-22-79) 
Sec. 2-87. - Adoption of administrative rules. 
    The pension and retirement committee shall adopt rules for the conduct of its business and administration of the plan as it considers desirable, provided they do not conflict with the plan. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 3, 1-22-79) 
Sec. 2-88. - Contracting for required services; costs. 
    The pension and retirement committee may authorize one or more of its members, or any agent, to act on its behalf and may contract for actuarial, legal, investment, advisory, medical, accounting, clerical and other services to carry out the plan. The costs of such services and expenses of the committee shall be paid by the town. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 4, 1-22-79) 
Sec. 2-89. - Authority in effectuating plan. 
    The pension and retirement committee may construe the plan, correct defects, supply omissions or reconcile inconsistencies to the extent necessary to effectuate the plan, and such action shall be conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 5, 1-22-79) 
Sec. 2-90. - Recordkeeping. 
    The pension and retirement committee shall keep records reflecting administration of the plan which shall be subject to audit by the town. Employees may examine records pertaining directly to them. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 6, 1-22-79) 
Sec. 2-91. - Liability. 
    No member of the pension and retirement committee shall be responsible for any action taken in good faith or for the exercise of any power given the pension and retirement committee or for the acts of other members. 
(Ord. No. 133, § 7, 1-22-79) 
Secs. 2-92-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SOCIAL SECURITY 

Sec. 2-111. - Application for membership and participation in Old-Age Survivors Insurance System; exceptions. 
    The town shall apply for membership and participation in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance System under title II of the Social Security Act, as amended, in accordance with G.S. § 7-452, retroactive to July 1, 1952, for all its employees, including positions on a fee basis which were excluded under the original agreement subject to the approval of the social security agency, with the exception of: 
(1)  Employees performing any services of an emergency nature while performing such services; 
(2)  All employees performing services in any classes of elective positions, part-time positions or positions the compensation for which is on a fee basis while performing such services; or 
(3)  The employees excluded by section 3 of Public Act No. 277. 
(Res. of 3-2-53; Res. of 3-23-55) 
Sec. 2-112. - Agreements with state employees' retirement commission. 
    The town shall execute any and all agreements with the state employees' retirement commission in accordance with and subject to the provisions of Public Act No. 277 and subject to the regulations promulgated by the state employees' retirement commission pursuant to such Public Act. 
(Res. of 3-2-53) 
Sec. 2-113. - Wage deductions. 
    The town shall be authorized and directed to make deductions from the wages of the employees participating in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance System as required by section 4 of Public Act No. 277, and to forward the amount thereof, together with the contribution of the town to the state employees' retirement commission, in a manner and form prescribed by such regulations. 
(Res. of 3-2-53) 
Sec. 2-114. - Additional appropriation for covering three percent social security tax. 
    An additional appropriation as recommended by the board of finance in the amount of $1,000.00 shall be made to cover the three percent social security tax, being the portion owed by both the town and its employees with the exceptions of those excepted in first resolution for the period from July 1, 1952, to the date of approval of the participation of the town in the Old-Age and Survivors Insurance System by the state employees' retirement commission, and to cover the town's portion for the balance of the fiscal year, 1952-53. 
(Res. of 3-2-53) 
Secs. 2-115-2-145. - Reserved.

If an individual shall fail to comply with this requirement, the town council shall remove such individual from the position to which said individual was most recently appointed or elected.

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the town, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the town or any evidence of the town's indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-11(1); any appropriation ordinance or ordinance providing for the levy of taxes or for an annual budget saved from repeal, § 1-11(2); taxation, ch. 94. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-226-2-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SALE OF TOWN-OWNED PROPERTY 

Sec. 2-246. - Planning and zoning review required. 
    Prior to offering any property for sale the council shall refer the proposal to the planning and zoning commission, as required by G.S. § 8-24. 
(Ord. No. 184, § 1, 10-5-92) 
Sec. 2-247. - Nonconforming lots. 
(a)  When the area of the parcel of real estate proposed for sale is less than required under existing zoning regulations, the following terms and conditions shall apply: It is the express intent of the council that preference be given to adjoining lot owners with existing dwellings to allow their properties to become more conforming with current zoning regulations. No new dwellings shall be allowed through the use of any variances, special exemption or special permits available through the zoning board of appeals or planning and zoning commission. The property shall remain as open space and shall carry a covenant that shall run with the land that absolutely prohibits any new construction above or below the ground of any kind, except: 
(1)  Additions or renovations to existing dwellings, including wells or septic tanks and fields; and 
(2)  If the building lot through a merger with another lot becomes a conforming lot in the zone. 
(b)  There shall be a minimum bid price equal to the sum of taxes, interest and lien fees owing on such parcel, or the assessed value, whichever sum is greater, except as set forth in this section. Additionally, the buyer shall be responsible for all legal expenses. 
(c)  The council shall sell such real estate by sealed bid, except as set forth in this section. All abutters shall be notified of the proposed sale by the town. 
(d)  The council may waive the requirements for the sale of a substandard lot by sealed bid or a minimum bid price whenever it shall find that the sale of such property to a particular abutting owner will benefit the health and general welfare of the community. 
(e)  The bidding shall first be limited to adjoining property owners. If no bids are received, the lake association in which the property is located shall have 30 days to express an interest in purchasing such lot for the sole purpose of open space. Subsequent bidding, if authorized by the council, shall be open to all persons and legally advertised at least ten days in advance. 
(f)  As an express condition of any acceptance of a bid to an adjoining property owner, the new lot shall be made a part of the existing property by deed restriction and can never be sold separately or split off from the property. 
(g)  It is further to be a condition of sale through a restrictive covenant that all wetlands will be protected and a conservation easement executed by the property owner to the town. 
(Ord. No. 184, § 2, 10-5-92) 
Sec. 2-248. - Conforming lots. 
(a)  When the area of the parcel of real estate proposed for sale is equal to or greater than required under existing zoning regulations for a building lot in the zone within which such parcel is located, the council shall sell such real estate by sealed bid. 
(b)  Bidding shall be open to all persons and advertised for sale in a legal notice at least ten days in advance. 
(c)  There shall be a minimum bid price equal to the sum of taxes, interest and lien fees owing on such parcel or the assessed value, whichever sum is greater. Additionally, the buyer shall be responsible for all legal expenses. 
(Ord. No. 184, § 3, 10-5-92) 
Secs. 2-249-2-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - INSURANCE ADVISORY COMMITTEE[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-146 et seq. 

Sec. 2-271. - Composition; terms; political affiliation. 
    There shall be an insurance advisory committee for the town consisting of five members appointed by the town council, one of whom shall be recommended by the board of education. The initial terms of office of two members shall be until July 1, 1976, and for the other three, until July 1, 1977. The terms of office shall be for two years thereafter. All committee members shall continue to serve until their successors are appointed and qualified. Their political affiliation shall be in accordance with section 2-2 of the town Charter and as section 2-2 may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 125, 4-7-75) 
Sec. 2-272. - Duties. 
    The insurance advisory committee shall: 
(1)  Annually review all insurance needs for the town; 
(2)  Recommend the inclusion or exclusion of town properties and/or personnel in insurance policies; 
(3)  Communicate with insurance companies or agents on behalf of the town; 
(4)  Prepare insurance bid specifications upon the request of the town manager or the board of education; and 
(5)  Review all town insurance policies annually. 
(Ord. No. 125, 4-7-75) 
Sec. 2-273. - Recommendations for insurance for inclusion in town budget. 
    The insurance advisory committee shall make its recommendations in writing for insurance to the town manager or the board of education for the following fiscal year in sufficient time for inclusion in the town budget at the annual town meeting. 
(Ord. No. 125, 4-7-75) 
Sec. 2-274. - Eligibility of insurance agencies and companies to submit bids for town's insurance; exceptions. 
    Any insurance agency or company licensed by the state and maintaining a full-time office with a full-time staff underwriting fire, liability and casualty insurance within a radius of 25 miles of the town hall shall be eligible to submit bids for insurance, except life and health insurance. 
(Ord. No. 125, 4-7-75) 
Sec. 2-275. - Administration of town insurance by agent of record; appointment. 
    All town insurance shall be administered by a single agent of record who shall provide the town with facilities and services for administering all claims of record for such purposes. The agent of record shall be appointed by the town manager with the approval of the town council. 
(Ord. No. 125, 4-7-75) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages in town parks and beaches, § 70-71. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Sunday sales. 
    The sale of alcoholic liquor shall be allowed in the town on Sundays, between the hours of 12:00 noon and 9:00 p.m. as provided in G.S. § 30-91a. 
(Ord. of 8-27-54) 
Editor's note- In accordance with the provisions of G.S. § 30-91a, the times during which alcoholic beverages may be sold is now specified by G.S. § 30-91. 
Secs. 6-2-6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POSSESSION OF ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES BY UNDERAGE PERSONS 

Sec. 6-31. - Findings. 
    The town council finds that the unregulated possession of alcoholic liquor by persons under the age of 21 is detrimental to the general welfare, health and safety of the citizens of Coventry, and especially its youth. 
(Ord. No. 222, § 1, 12-20-04) 
Sec. 6-32. - Definitions. 
    Alcoholic liquor shall have the same meaning as the term is defined in section 30-1 of the Connecticut General Statutes, as it may be amended from time to time. 
    Host shall mean to organize an event or gathering of or for two or more persons, or to allow any premises under one's possession or control to be used with one's knowledge for an event or gathering of or for two or more persons, whether for personal, social or business interaction. 
(Ord. No. 222, § 1, 12-20-04) 
Sec. 6-33. - Possession of alcoholic liquor restricted. 
    No person under the age of 21 shall possess any alcoholic liquor within the town except as provided in section 6-35. This restriction shall apply to both public and private property. 
(Ord. No. 222, § 1, 12-20-04) 
Sec. 6-34. - Restrictions on hosting an event or gathering. 
    No person shall host an event or gathering at which alcoholic liquor is provided or made available to any person who has not attained the age of 21 years except as provided in section 6-35. This prohibition shall apply to any event or gathering within the town, whether conducted on public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 222, § 1, 12-20-04) 
Sec. 6-35. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing in this article shall be deemed to prohibit the possession of alcoholic beverages by, or the provision of alcoholic beverages to, a person who had not attained the age of 21 years: 
(1)  When such person is accompanied by or in the presence of such person's parent, guardian, or spouse who has attained the age of 21 years. 
(2)  When such person is provided with or is in possession of such alcoholic beverages solely in the course of such person's obligations or duties as an employee of a business enterprise holding a valid Connecticut license to serve, sell or otherwise provide such alcoholic beverages to persons who have attained the age or 21 years. 
(3)  When such person is provided with or is in possession of such alcoholic beverages solely in fulfillment of a prescription or order by a licensed, practicing physician. 
(Ord. No. 222, § 1, 12-20-04) 
Sec. 6-36. - Enforcement. 
    The chief of police, or any member of the Coventry Police Department, may enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 222, § 1, 12-20-04) 
Sec. 6-37. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person violating sections 6-33 or 6-34 shall be subject to a fine of $90.00 for each such violation. 
(Ord. No. 222, § 1, 12-20-04; Ord. No. 224, § 1, 3-7-05) 
Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS 

Sec. 10-1. - State law relating to bazaars and raffles adopted. 
    The town adopts the provisions of G.S. §§ 7-170-7-186, as amended, inclusive, to permit the conduct of bazaars and raffles, subject to the regulations, restrictions and requirements of such statutes. 
(Ord. No. 159, 8-15-88) 
Sec. 10-2. - State bingo law adopted. 
    The playing of bingo in the town, as provided in G.S. § 7-169, shall be permitted. 
(Res. of 9-15-53) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals prohibited in parks and beaches, § 70-74. 

Sec. 14-1. - Geese. 
    All geese that shall be found upon the commons shall be forfeited to any that take them up. 
(Ord. of 2-21-1725) 
Sec. 14-2. - Horses. 
    No horse shall be allowed to go at large on the highway or commons in the town. If any horse shall be so found going at large on the highways or commons it shall be the duty of the haywards appointed by the town, and it shall be lawful for any landholder in the town, or by his order, to impound such horse in the pound nearest the place where taken. The owner of such horse shall pay the sum of $1.00 for each horse before the horse shall be released from the pound. Three-quarters of the sum shall be paid to the person who shall impound such horse, and one-quarter of the sum shall be paid to the poundkeeper for his fee. The liberation or discharge of such horse from the pound, or other disposition of the horse, when impounded, shall be regulated and conducted in conformity with G.S. § 22-368 et seq. 
(Ord. of 12-5-1809) 
Cross reference- Riding of horses in parks and beaches, § 70-76. 
Sec. 14-3. - Swine. 
    All swine, boars excepted, may be allowed to go at large on the highway or commons, provided they have a ring in their nose and pigs under three months old without rings. If any boar over three months old shall be found going at large on the highways or commons in the town, it shall be the duty of the haywards appointed by the town, and it shall be lawful for any landholder in the town, or by their order, to impound any such boar in the pound nearest the place where so found. The owner of such boar shall pay the sum of $2.00 for each boar before the boar shall be released from the pound. Three-quarters of the sum shall be paid to the person who shall impound such boar, and one-quarter of the sum shall be paid to the poundkeeper for his fee. The liberation or discharge of such boar from the pound or other disposition of the boar, when impounded, shall be regulated and conducted in conformity with G.S. § 22-368 et seq. 
(Ord. of 1-16-1810) 
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; flood and erosion control board, ch. 46; historic preservation, ch. 54; planning and land use, ch. 78; solid waste, ch. 82; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; subdivisions, ch. 90; utilities, ch. 102. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Permit, inspection and review fees-Generally. 
(a)  New construction and alterations. The fee for a building permit and all mechanical permits shall be based on the value of the work being done, and shall be charged at the rate of $15.00 per $1,000.00 of value or part thereof. The foregoing fee does not include the education fee required by G.S. § 29-263(b), which fee shall be separately charged and must also be paid by the applicant prior to the issuance of the building permit. The calculation of the value of the work shall be based on the most recent schedule established by the International Code Council, Inc., by the Marshall and Swift building cost handbook, or by any other nationally recognized pricing schedule. All fees and costs related to the performance of special, professional and technical services for threshold limit structures, as defined in G.S., § 29-276(b), shall be paid by the owner. Notwithstanding, the building official is authorized to waive all town fees related to building permits for work on crumbling foundations which, based upon the judgment of the building official, are casually related to a reaction to Pyrrhotite or related reasons rather than improper workmanship. Said waiver may include fees for electrical, plumbing or similar fees at the discretion of the building official. 
    Any such waiver shall only apply to work related to the direct replacement of the existing foundation. Upon waiver of any such fee, the building official shall notify the homeowner in writing that such fee has been waived, including an itemization of all fees waived. The building official shall report to the council by January 15th and July 15th of each year setting forth the value of the work and the amount of fees that have been waived, as well as the progress made in repairing said properties and returning them to their fair valuation. 
    This waiver provision shall be effective January 1, 2017. Work that has commenced, but not completed, prior to this effective date may be eligible for a refund of any fees previously paid. 
(b)  Moving of buildings. The fee for a permit for the moving of buildings shall be $15.00 per $1,000.00 of the reasonable cost of such move, including the cost of foundations and all other work associated with the movement and placement of the structure. A contract for such work may be considered as evidence of the reasonable cost, but shall not be binding on the town. 
(c)  Demolition. The fee for a demolition permit for a building shall be $15.00 per $1,000.00 of the assessed value of the building per the current assessor's card. The minimum fee shall be $30.00 and the maximum fee shall be $150.00. 
(d)  Solid fuel stoves, gas or liquid fuel inserts units. The fee for inspection of the installation of a solid fuel stove shall be $30.00, except that, where such installation includes a chimney, the fee shall be $45.00. 
(e)  Repeat inspections and return visits. A fee of $25.00 shall be paid for each second or later inspection of site work caused by either the failure of the owner or builder to make the site ready for inspection at the proper time, or the failure to correct a building code violation previously inspected and noted. 
(f)  Starting work without a permit. The fee for the review of work, as defined in the state building code, started without the proper permits shall be $100.00, 
(g)  Building plan review. The fee for the review of plans for residences and commercial and industrial buildings shall be $75.00. If the same plans are used for the purpose of obtaining a building permit, the plan review fee shall be deemed to be included within the overall building permit fee, as established pursuant to subsection (a). If a plan review fee was paid prior to the issuance of such building permit, the plan review fee shall be credited against the total building permit fee. 
(Ord. No. 195, §§ 1-7, 6-3-96; Ord. No. 210, § 1, 7-17-00; Ord. No. 233, 2-22-11; Ord. No. 251, 2-21-17) 
Sec. 18-2. - Same-Municipal projects. 
    The fees for permits on municipal projects, now a requirement under the zoning laws and the building code in the town, shall be eliminated. 
(Ord. of 12-9-63; Ord. No. 251, 2-21-17) 
Sec. 18-3. - Building in an unapproved subdivision or on an unaccepted street or road. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsections (b), (c), (d) and (e) of this section, no building permit shall be issued and no building or other structure shall be erected in an unapproved subdivision or on any lot abutting an unaccepted street. Any building or other structure erected in violation of this section shall be deemed unlawful, and the town may commence an action to enjoin the erection of such structure, or cause the structure to be removed. Any person erecting a building or other structure in violation of this section shall be fined not more than as provided in section 1-10 of the Code of Ordinances for each structure so erected, in addition to the relief otherwise available to the town. 
(b)  For the purposes of subsection (a), the term "street" shall be deemed to include the terms "road" and "highway" and shall include both public and private streets, but it shall not be deemed to include driveways, parking areas, or other areas that are or may be provided for motor vehicle circulation or parking solely within individual lots. The provisions of subsection (a) shall not be deemed to apply to any lot abutting both an accepted street and an unaccepted street if primary access to the building site is or will be on the accepted street. 
(c)  This section shall not prevent the issuance of a building permit for the renovation, repair, or alteration of any building or other structure that was in existence on the effective date of this section, provided such renovation, alteration or expansion is not intended or designed to increase the number of families or business entities that occupy any lot. In addition, this section shall not prohibit the construction of farm accessory buildings that are not otherwise in violation of any zoning or building regulations of the town. 
(d)  A building permit may be issued for the erection of buildings or other structures on lots abutting an unaccepted street if all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  A lawfully established property owners' association owns or has legal responsibility for the maintenance of the street, as reflected in the land records of the town; and 
(2)  The street has been continuously maintained by the town and/or a property owners' association up until the date the building permit is to be issued. 
    For the purposes of this subsection, the term "continuously maintained" means that the street has regularly (but not necessarily daily or on any other specific schedule) received such maintenance as has been reasonably necessary to allow safe travel by motor vehicles (for example, paving, grading, drainage, and snow and ice removal). 
(e)  A building permit may also be issued for the erection of buildings or other structures on lots abutting an unaccepted street if all of the following conditions exist or are met: 
(1)  The physical condition of such street, including any associated improvements, is adequate to allow the use of such street by motor vehicles without unreasonable risk or danger to the public health, safety and welfare; 
(2)  Adequate arrangements are made by the subdivision developer, landowner, prospective builder or other private party for continuing maintenance of the street until such time as the street is accepted by the town. Such arrangements must be made in the form of a written agreement with the town and must include adequate financial security, all of which must be approved as to form by the town attorney; 
(3)  The subdivision developer, landowner, prospective builder or other private party provides a policy of insurance, naming the town as the insured or as an additional insured, against all claims for personal and property damage caused by or arising from the condition of the street. The minimum amount of such insurance coverage shall be $2,000,000 per person per claim for personal injury and $2,000,000 per claim for property damage. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to make the town liable for any such personal injury or property damage or to relieve the subdivision developer, landowner, prospective builder or other private party from any and all liability such party may otherwise have for such injury or damage. 
(Ord. of 1-31-61; Ord. No. 223, § 1, 2-7-05) 
Sec. 18-4. - Withholding of building permits when taxes or sewer charges are delinquent. 
(a)  Before any application for a building permit may be approved by the building official or other authorized agent of the town, such official or agent shall consult with the office of the tax collector to determine whether any property taxes or any sewer charges, rates, or assessments are delinquent for the property for which the application has been made. 
(b)  In the event the office of the tax collector determines that any such property taxes or sewer charges, rates or assessments are delinquent, such application for a building permit shall not be approved, except as provided in subsection (e) below, and the building official or other authorized agent of the town shall stamp or write the words "approval withheld per tax collector" on such application. 
(c)  Except as provided in subsection (e) below, the building official or other authorized agent of the town may not approve any application for a building permit unless and until the office of the tax collector advises such official or agent that there are no delinquent property taxes or sewer charges, rates, or assessments relating to the property for which the application has been made. 
(d)  Except as provided in subsection (e) below, the approval of any application for a building permit for property for which any property taxes or any sewer charges, rates or assessments are delinquent shall be deemed void and of no legal effect if such approval was given at any time during which such delinquency existed. If the delinquent amounts are fully paid after such invalid approval is granted, the building permit shall not be fully validated and effective until a new approval is endorsed on such application by the building official or other authorized agent of the town after consulting with the office of the tax collector. 
(e)  In the event the town manager determines that the approval of an application for a building permit is necessary for, or would substantially promote, the public health by remediating or removing a nuisance or other conditions detrimental to the public, or that such approval would otherwise facilitate the payment of delinquent property taxes or sewer charges, rates, or assessments, the town manager may authorize the building official or other authorized agent of the town to issue such building permit despite the existence of any such delinquency. Such approval shall be made in writing. The town manager must condition any such approval on an agreement by the applicant to pay the balance of the overdue taxes, charges, rates, or assessments by a date certain or in accordance with a fixed schedule, unless the town council waives such requirement upon the request of the applicant for good cause shown. 
(Ord. No. 202, §§ 1-5, 5-3-99; Ord. No. 209, § 1, 7-17-00) 
Sec. 18-5. - Maintenance of unaccepted streets. 
    Any person who owns or controls a street or portion of a street that was constructed pursuant to the approval by the planning and zoning commission of subdivision plans on which such construction had been proposed, but that has not yet been accepted by the town, shall be responsible for maintaining the physical condition of the street in a safe condition for vehicular passage by all persons who are allowed or authorized to use such street, including, but not limited to, any persons who have acquired lots within the approved subdivision. Such responsibilities shall include routine winter maintenance, such as plowing, snow removal, sanding and salting when appropriate. In the event such maintenance is not provided as required by this section, the town may, but shall not be obligated to, supply such maintenance, and any person who owns or controls such unaccepted street or portion thereof shall be liable to reimburse the town for the costs and expenses of such maintenance, including all costs, including reasonable attorneys' fees, the town may incur in order to obtain such reimbursement. 
(Ord. No. 223, § 2, 2-7-05) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 223, § 2, adopted Feb. 7, 2005, supplied provisions to be added to this Code as § 18-4. In order to maintain the established section numbers, at the discretion of the editor, these provisions have been included herein as § 18-5. 
Secs. 18-6-18-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BLIGHT ORDINANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 230, adopted Jan. 4, 2010, amended art. II in its entirety and enacted the provisions set out herein. The former art. II, titled Housing Code, derived from Ord. No. 102, §§ 1.01, 1.03, 3.01-3.09, 4.01-4.05, 5.01-5.05, 6.01, 6.02, 7.01-7.09, 8.01-8.08, 9.01-9.06, 10.01-10.03, 11.01, 11.02, 14.02, 18.03, II, IV-X, XII, XVI, XV, and XVII, adopted Feb. 1, 1971. 

Sec. 18-36. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Blight Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 230, 1-4-10) 
Sec. 18-37. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to define, prohibit and abate blights and to protect, preserve, and promote public health, safety and welfare; and to preserve and protect property values within the town as authorized under G.S. § 7-148. 
(Ord. No. 230, 1-4-10) 
Sec. 18-38. - Scope of provisions. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall limit the applicability or scope of state laws and/or town ordinances and regulations governing the use of real property, including regulations governing agricultural land, public or semipublic open space, and inland wetlands, watercourses and upland review areas. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall restrict the preservation through conservation easements of land in its natural state. 
(Ord. No. 230, 1-4-10) 
Sec. 18-39. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article: 
    Blight or blighted : 
(a)  Any structure which is in a state of dilapidation or decay; or is open to the elements as a result of damage, dilapidation or decay; or unable to provide shelter, or serve the purpose for which it was constructed due to damage, dilapidation, or decay; 
(b)  Premises occupied by a structure intended for human occupancy, in which weeds or similar vegetation (excluding flowers, fruits and vegetables, and areas maintained in their original naturally wooded state, or natural field state) is allowed to reach and remain at a height of 36 inches or greater for a period of thirty days or longer; 
(c)  Dead, decayed, diseased or damaged trees constituting a hazard or danger to persons or property; 
(d)  Two or more unregistered motor vehicles in the public view pursuant to G.S. § 14-150a; 
(e)  Residentially zoned property with any combination of five or more pieces of mechanical equipment stored on the premises and in the public view; 
(f)  Residential or commercially zoned property that has any of the following conditions: 
1.  Premises containing accumulated debris, not including compost piles or piles of grass and/or brush which are not visible from a public right-of-way and do not otherwise constitute a public health or safety hazard; or 
2.  Landscaping, including but not limited to, trees, shrubs, hedges, grass, and plants, on any premises which physically hinder or interfere with the lawful use of abutting premises or block or interfere with the use of any public sidewalk and/or private street or right-of-way or any road sign. 
    Debris: Material which is incapable of immediately performing the function for which it was designed including, but not limited to, abandoned, discarded, or unused objects; junk comprised of equipment such as automobiles, boats, and recreation vehicles which are unregistered and missing parts, not complete in appearance and in an obvious state of disrepair; parts of automobiles, furniture, appliances, cans, boxes, scrap metal, tires, batteries, containers, and garbage which are in the public view. 
    Decay: A wasting or wearing away; a gradual decline in strength, soundness or quality; to become decomposed or rotten as evidenced by the lack of maintenance including, but not limited to, the following conditions: missing or boarded windows and doors; collapsing or missing walls, roofs, seriously damaged or missing siding, gutters, a structurally faulty foundation. 
    Dilapidated: Decayed or rotten beyond repair. 
    Mechanical equipment: Any apparatus designed to operate by an internal combustion engine, or designed to be towed by an apparatus propelled by an internal combustion engine. 
    Natural field state: Areas where grass, weeds, and brush exist in their natural, unlandscaped state. 
    Natural wooded state: Areas where trees and brush exist in their natural, unlandscaped state. 
    Person: Any man, woman, corporation, or other legal entity capable of owning or leasing real property. 
    Premises: A platted lot or part thereof or unplatted lot or parcel of land or plot of land, either occupied or unoccupied by any dwelling or nondwelling structure and includes any such building, accessory structure or other structure thereon, or any part thereof. The term "premises," where the context requires, shall be deemed to include any buildings, dwellings, parcels or land or structures contained within the scope of this ordinance. 
    Public view: Visible from any public right-of-way or neighboring property. 
    Structure: Any building, dwelling, fence, swimming pool, or similarly constructed object. 
(Ord. No. 230, 1-4-10) 
Sec. 18-40. - Prohibition against creation or maintenance of blight; responsibility for compliance. 
(a)  No person shall cause or allow blighted premises or structures to be created or maintained in the town. 
(b)  The owner of premises subject to this article shall be obligated to comply with the provisions of this article. In the event that the relevant building or structure or portion of a building or structure is known by the town manager or his designees to be occupied by or under the legal control or possession of a person other than the owner, the town manager or his designee may direct a similar notice and order to any such person whom they may reasonably believe to be fully or partially responsible for creating or maintaining the blighted condition. Each person receiving such notice and order shall be deemed to be jointly and severally liable for correcting the blighted or unsafe conditions. 
(Ord. No. 230, 1-4-10) 
Sec. 18-41. - Notice of violations. 
(a)  Complaints may be submitted to the town manager or his/her designee by members of the public, but to be timely and effectively investigated such complaints should be in writing and signed on forms provided by the town. Anonymous or unsigned complaints will be assigned a lower investigative priority and will be reviewed as time allows. Further, nothing in this article shall prohibit or prevent town staff from initiating an investigation. 
(b)  Whenever the town manager or his/her designee determines that there has been a violation of any such provision of this article, except as to section 18-39(d), such officer shall give notice of such violation to the person responsible therefore, as hereinafter provided. Such violation shall: 
(1)  Be in writing. 
(2)  Set forth the violations of this article. 
(3)  Specify a final date for the correction of any violation. 
(4)  Be served upon the owner or the owner's agent, or the occupant as the case may require; provided, such notice shall be deemed to be properly served upon such owner or agent, or upon such occupant, if a copy thereof is posted in a conspicuous place in or about the dwelling affected by this notice; or is sent by certified mail to the owner of the property at his or her last known address. 
(5)  State that the penalties and enforcement provisions of this article will become effective on the final date set for the correction of any violation. 
(6)  A notice of the right to appeal in accordance with section 18-43. 
(c)  Whenever the town manager or his/her designee determines that there has been a violation of subsection 18-39(d) pertaining to unregistered motor vehicles, such officer shall give notice of such violation to the person responsible therefore which notice shall be in compliance with subsection 18-41(a), except that: 
(1)  The notice shall specify that the owner has 30 days to correct the violation by removing the vehicle or registering it; and 
(2)  Notice of the alleged violation shall be published in a newspaper having a substantial circulation in the town. 
(d)  Any person notified in accordance with this section who fails to correct any violation by the date specified in said notice shall be in violation of this ordinance and subject to its penalties and enforcement procedures. Any person in violation of subsection 18-39(d) 30 days after notice of alleged violation in accordance with subsection 18-41(b) above, shall be subject to the removal and disposition of the unregistered motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 230, 1-4-10) 
Sec. 18-42. - Special consideration. 
    Special consideration may be given to those who require it in order to correct a violation of this article. Specifically, the enforcement officer may grant a property owner additional time to correct a violation where the owner establishes good cause. As used in this section, "good cause" includes, but is not limited to, an elderly individual who is unable to personally correct a problem due to age, a disabled individual or other individual who is unable to personally correct a problem due to a medical condition, or an individual who earns a low income and is unable to correct a problem due to cost. In determining whether good cause exists, the enforcement officer shall consider whether other occupants of a property are able to assist in correcting the problem in a timely fashion and whether the severity of the problem is such that additional time is not warranted. If the items designated as blighted have to do with lawn and shrub maintenance and/or keeping the grounds free from rubbish and debris, or constitute a fire or safety hazard, the enforcement officer shall not provide additional time to correct the problem. 
(Ord. No. 230, 1-4-10) 
Sec. 18-43. - Appeals. 
    Any person notified in accordance with section 18-41 above may appeal said notice violation(s) to the building code board of appeals, in writing, within 10 days of the date of receipt of said notice or 20 days from the issuance of said notice, whichever is shorter. If an appeal is taken as aforesaid, the first day of violation shall be seven days after the decision of the building code board of appeals or on such later date as established by the building code board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 230, 1-4-10) 
Sec. 18-44. - Penalties and enforcement. 
(a)  Penalties. 
(1)  Each violation of this article shall be considered a separate municipal offense. 
(2)  Each day any violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(3)  Each separate offense under this article shall be punishable by a fine of $100.00 payable to the town. Failure to pay fines when due may be enforced in the superior court, including the centralized infractions bureau. 
(b)  Enforcement. 
(1)  The town manager, his/her designee, or any police officer in the town is authorized to issue a citation or summons for a violation of this article. 
(2)  In addition thereto, the town manager, or his/her designee, is authorized to initiate legal proceedings in the superior court for the immediate correction of the violation(s), collection of any penalties, and the recovery of all costs including costs of remedial action(s) authorized by the court and reasonable attorney's fees incurred by the town to enforce this article. 
(3)  All fines, court costs, costs of remedial action, and attorney's fees, as ordered by the court, shall constitute a lien on the subject premises, provided the owner of said premises has been notified of the violations as herein provided and was made party to the enforcement proceedings. Any such lien shall be recorded on the Coventry Land Records. 
(Ord. No. 230, 1-4-10) 
Sec. 18-45. - Entry, inspection and remediation. 
    If the town manager or his or her designee reasonably believes that blight exists on a property, he or she is authorized to enter the property during reasonable hours for the purpose of inspection and remediation of any blighted condition, provided such person shall not be authorized to enter any dwelling house or structure on the property. 
(Ord. No. 230, 1-4-10; Ord. No. 232, 1-18-11) 
Sec. 18-46. - Other law. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other statutes, codes, ordinances or regulations which prescribe standards other than those provided for in this article. 
(b)  In any case where a provision of this article is found to be in conflict with a provision of any zoning, building, fire, safety or health ordinance, regulation or other code of the town or state, the provision which establishes the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety, and property values of the people shall prevail. 
(c)  This article shall not affect violations of any other ordinances, code or regulation existing prior to the effective date of this Code, and any such violations may be governed and continue to be punishable under the provisions of those ordinances, codes or regulations in effect at the time the violation was committed. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall be deemed to prohibit the town, acting through its building official, from enforcing the provisions of sections 120.0 through 122.4 of the State Basic Building Code, as amended, as it applies to unsafe structures, fire-damaged structures or deteriorated structures and the demolition and/or removal of the same. 
(Ord. No. 230, 1-4-10) 
Chapter 22 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Authority to establish, maintain and operate cemeteries, G.S. § 7-148(c)(6)(A)(i). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Short title of chapter. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Coventry Municipal Cemetery Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 131, § 1, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cemetery means the municipal cemetery of the town and any and all town-owned cemeteries. 
    Commission is the cemetery commission of the town. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of the cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 2, 7-18-77) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-3. - Duties of superintendent. 
    Should a superintendent be employed, his duties are to: 
(1)  Direct the cemetery. The superintendent shall look after and take proper care of the cemetery and see that no lot therein is used or occupied in violation of this chapter or of any rule or regulation promulgated by the commission. 
(2)  Collect and surrender fees. All fees and charges collected by the superintendent for duties and services performed in connection with the cemetery shall be immediately surrendered to the commission. 
(3)  Supervise interment. The superintendent shall oversee the digging of graves and properly inter the dead when called upon to do so. 
(4)  Perform additional duties or duties in lieu of those listed in this section. The superintendent shall perform such additional duties or duties in lieu of those listed in this section as may be determined by the commission. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 10, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-4. - Rules for interment. 
    No deceased person shall be interred in the cemetery until the superintendent or a member of the commission has found that: 
(1)  A burial permit has been obtained from the public health officer as required by law; 
(2)  The lot in which burial is to be made is fully paid for; 
(3)  The person arranging for the burial has the right to the use of such lot; 
(4)  Such lot is not used beyond its capacity; and 
(5)  Proper record is made of the name and age of the deceased person and the exact location of the grave. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 12, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-5. - Lot valuation; method of purchase. 
(a)  The commission shall place a value upon all unsold lots in the cemetery, and shall record such valuations on an official map or plan of such cemetery that shall be kept on file, open to public inspection, in the office of the commission. Such official valuations shall be the price at which such lots shall be sold. 
(b)  The commission may revalue unsold lots from time to time as may be necessary. Such revaluations shall be recorded on an official map or plan of such cemetery that shall be kept on file, open to public inspection, in the office of the commission. 
(c)  There shall be no discrimination in the sale of lots on the basis of sex, race or religious preference. 
(d)  Any person desiring to purchase a particular lot, for the purpose for which it is intended, shall be permitted to do so upon payment of the price fixed for such lot or upon making arrangements, according to rules and regulations that may be established by the commission, for the purchase of such lot on the installment plan. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 13, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-6. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-10. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 15, 7-18-77) 
Secs. 22-7-22-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CEMETERY COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-146 et seq. 

Sec. 22-41. - Appointment of members; terms; compensation. 
    The town council shall appoint five persons who are residents of the town, who shall constitute and be called the cemetery commission. Their terms shall be staggered, and they shall hold their positions for three years and until their successors are duly appointed and qualified. Members of the cemetery commission shall serve without pay. The initial terms of the members of the commission shall be adjusted by the town council to allow for staggered terms. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 3, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-42. - Quorum; meetings; bylaws and rules; appointment of officers. 
(a)  A majority of the members of the commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and they may hold general or special meetings at the town hall or elsewhere, at such times as they may by order direct. Such majority may make and establish such reasonable bylaws, rules and regulations as may be necessary for their own government, and for the full and complete execution of their powers and duties and the use, including resale or transfer of lots by owners, of town-owned cemeteries. 
(b)  The commission shall organize, selecting one of their number to be chairman and another to be clerk. The commission shall also select a treasurer, who shall not be a member of the commission. Such treasurer shall serve for a period of three years and until his successor is duly appointed and qualified and shall receive such compensation, if any, as determined by the commission and ratified by the town council. Such treasurer shall not be considered a town employee. His compensation, if any, shall neither be paid from the town general fund, nor included in the town annual budget, but rather shall be paid from commission funds. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 4, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-43. - Treasurer. 
(a)  The treasurer, before entering upon his duties as such, shall execute a bond in the penal sum of not less than double the value of funds actually coming or anticipated to be coming into his hands as such treasurer, conditioned on the faithful performance of his duties and for the faithful accounting for all money or funds which by virtue of this office, comes into his hands, and to be in such form and with such securities as may be prescribed and approved by the town council, to be approved and preserved in the same manner as is the bond of the treasurer of the town. 
(b)  The treasurer of the commission shall have the custody of all money and property received by the commission from all sources, and shall pay out the same only upon the written order of the commission, signed by the chairman and clerk of the commission. He shall keep permanent books of records of all such funds, and all receipts and disbursements thereof, and for what purposes such funds are received and disbursed. The treasurer shall make an annual written report, under oath, to the commission and to the town council. Such written report shall show balances, receipts and disbursements, including a statement showing the amount and principal of trust funds on hand and how invested, which report shall be audited by the town auditor, and if found correct, shall be transmitted to the town council at the same time that the treasurer of the town is required by law to make his report. Such report shall be approved and preserved in the same manner, and reported in the annual report of the town, if found to be correct. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 5, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-44. - Clerk. 
    The clerk of the commission shall keep a permanent record of the proceedings of the commission in a book provided for that purpose, and shall also keep a permanent record of the funds, including trust funds, from what sources received, the amounts thereof and for what uses and purposes, respectively, and he shall annually, at the time of transmitting the treasurer's report to the town council, make a report in writing under oath, to the town council, stating therein substantially the same matters required to be reported by the treasurer of the commission. Such report, if found correct, shall be approved and preserved by the town council. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 6, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-45. - Powers of town council. 
(a)  The town council shall have the power to remove from office any member of the commission or the treasurer for nonperformance of duties or for misappropriation or wrongful use of funds or property, and to require a just and proper accounting for the same. 
(b)  The commission shall have the care, charge, management and control of such cemetery, under the supervision of the town council. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 7, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-46. - Duties. 
(a)  The commission shall control, manage and direct the acquisition, apportionment, use and disposition of all town-owned cemetery properties and their appurtenances, including land, plantings, buildings and equipment related thereto, and to maintain these properties and appurtenances. 
(b)  The commission shall have the power and authority to contract for the services of, and define the duties of a competent superintendent for the cemetery properties. His contract shall be fixed by the commission and paid by the commission. Such superintendent shall be subject to removal at any time by the commission. 
(c)  The superintendent shall not be considered a town employee. His compensation shall neither be paid from the town general fund, nor included in the town annual budget, but rather shall be paid from commission funds. 
(d)  The commission, shall, prior to the start of development of any cemeteries, prepare and submit to the town council for approval a comprehensive financial plan, including repayment of costs of land purchase, if any; engineering and legal fees; and other costs, which shall establish the cemetery on a fiscally self-sufficient basis, imposing no costs to the town general fund or annual budget. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 8, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-47. - Fund management. 
(a)  Funds for the acquisition of cemetery property, designs of cemetery layout and lot locations, maintenance and other necessary costs shall be maintained separately from the town's general fund and annual budget. Funds received by the commission from lot sales, burial fees and any other fees received shall be maintained in a separate account and only be used for cemetery maintenance, repayment of bonds, design and development, and related costs. 
(b)  Upon recommendation of the cemetery commission, surplus funds may be used for improvements, acquisition of additional cemetery property or other related purposes approved by a town meeting. Should the commission, in concurrence with the town council, and if approved by a town meeting, deem that there are surplus funds in excess of the legitimate needs of the cemetery commission, such funds shall be returned to the town general fund. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 9, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-48. - Rules and regulations. 
    The commission shall establish and make available to town residents rules and regulations for the use of the cemetery relating to: 
(1)  Subdivision of the cemetery into lots; 
(2)  Capacity of each lot; 
(3)  Location of graves; 
(4)  Type of plantings, monuments and markers that will be permitted for the proper and most attractive development of town-owned cemetery properties; 
(5)  Limitations on purchase and on the terms, conditions and recording of the resale of the lots; 
(6)  The setting of fees and the collection thereof for services performed in connection with the cemetery; 
(7)  All matters within the scope of duties of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 11, 7-18-77) 
Sec. 22-49. - Records of ownership. 
    The commission shall keep full and complete records of the ownership of all lots in the cemetery, of the burial capacity of each lot, sold or unsold, of the location of each grave, of the names of the persons buried in each grave that has been or shall hereafter be used for burial, and of the date of burial of each. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 14, 7-18-77) 
Secs. 22-50-22-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - USE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 22-81. - Purchase of burial rights. 
    Qualified residents, former residents and nonresidents may purchase burial rights in lots within cemeteries at prices which shall be determined from time to time by the cemetery commission. Such rights are not transferrable, but must be resold to the town at the purchase price, less a $10.00 handling fee, and without interest. Persons holding such burial rights will be referred to as "lot owners" in succeeding sections of this article. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 1, 6-25-84) 
Sec. 22-82. - Cemetery hours. 
    Cemeteries will be open from sunrise to one-half hour after sunset. No person shall be allowed on cemetery property after dark. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 2, 6-25-84) 
Sec. 22-83. - Damage or destruction to cemetery property. 
    Persons visiting cemeteries are prohibited from picking flowers, breaking or injuring trees, shrubs, or plants, or from writing upon, defacing, or damaging any memorials, fences or other structure within cemetery grounds. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 3, 6-25-84) 
Sec. 22-84. - Operation of motor vehicles. 
    Driving a motor vehicle on any grassed area without the express permission of the superintendent of the cemetery, or his agent, is prohibited. Driving a motor vehicle in any cemetery at a speed in excess of 15 miles per hour is also prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 4, 6-25-84) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 98. 
Sec. 22-85. - Vehicles and horses prohibited on grassy areas. 
    No bicycle, motorcycle, minibike, motor scooter, snowmobile or horses will be allowed on any grassed area of cemetery grounds. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 5, 6-25-84) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 98. 
Sec. 22-86. - Firearms and other dangerous weapons prohibited; exception. 
    Bringing firearms or other dangerous weapons into cemeteries, except by a military escort accompanying a veteran's funeral or attending memorial services, is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 6, 6-25-84) 
Sec. 22-87. - Waste disposal. 
    Throwing rubbish on the drives or paths, or any part of the grounds, is prohibited. Waste material shall be placed in receptacles, if available, or removed from cemetery grounds. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 7, 6-25-84) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 82. 
Sec. 22-88. - Prohibited acts. 
    There shall be strict observance of the proprieties in the cemeteries. No person within a cemetery shall engage in any of the following acts: 
(1)  Loud and boisterous talking; 
(2)  Idling or loafing on the grounds; 
(3)  Bringing lunches, refreshments or alcoholic beverages into a cemetery, or consuming them on the grounds; 
(4)  Peddling or soliciting the sale of any commodity within a cemetery; or 
(5)  Placing signs or notices or advertisements of any kind within a cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 8, 6-25-84) 
Sec. 22-89. - Traffic control signs. 
    Traffic control signs placed in any cemetery must be obeyed. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 9, 6-25-84) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 98. 
Sec. 22-90. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Pursuant to G.S. § 19-148, any person who knowingly violates the bylaws set out in this article shall be fined not more than $10.00. 
(Ord. No. 139, § 10, 6-25-84) 
Chapter 26 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; law enforcement, ch. 62. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Establishing command of all local government functions in the event of a disaster. 
(a)  In the event of disaster, the town manager will assume complete command of all local government functions and facilities including, through the superintendent of schools, or his designate, public school facilities and personnel. All available local resources will be brought to bear on the disaster existent in an effort to protect and preserve human life and property of the community, to the greatest extent possible. 
(b)  The authority of the town manager shall be limited only by the governor of the state in state-declared emergencies or the President of the United States of America in a declared national emergency. 
(Ord. No. 124, 3-3-75) 
Secs. 26-2-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CIVIL PREPAREDNESS AGENCY 

Sec. 26-31. - Establishment; supervision by coordinator; removal of coordinator. 
    There shall be created an agency of town government to be known as the civil preparedness agency. Such agency shall be under the supervision of a coordinator of all disaster emergency functions. Such coordinator of the civil preparedness agency shall be appointed by the town manager. The coordinator of the civil preparedness agency will serve at the will of the town manager and may be removed by the town manager at any time. The coordinator may also be removed from his position as provided in G.S. § 28-7(b). 
(Ord. No. 123, 1-6-75) 
Sec. 26-32. - Duties and powers of coordinator. 
(a)  The coordinator of the civil preparedness agency is a staffperson reporting directly to the town manager. 
(b)  As a staffperson, the coordinator will advise the town manager on matters pertaining to civil preparedness and disaster emergency operations. He will coordinate the activities of all town agencies in disaster emergency situations, but in no case will he assume command of any agency or department other than the civil preparedness agency unless directly ordered to do so by the town manager. 
(c)  The coordinator will coordinate the activities of all civil preparedness agency forces, both full-time and volunteer, and will be responsible for the recruitment and training of needed civil preparedness personnel. As a staffperson he will assist the town manager in the preparation and updating of town emergency operations plans and standing operating procedures. 
(d)  The coordinator will maintain contact with the state civil preparedness area office designated for the town and will cooperate with the state civil preparedness agency in preparation of required reports, procedures and other necessary paper work to ensure the town's receiving all possible funding, equipment and benefits available to the town through state and national civil preparedness. 
(e)  The coordinator will perform such other civil preparedness related functions as may, from time to time, be assigned to him by the town manager. 
Sec. 26-33. - Compensation of coordinator. 
    The coordinator of the civil preparedness agency shall receive such compensation for performance of his duties as may be determined by the town council. 
(Ord. No. 123, 1-6-75)

(Ord. No. 194, 4-22-96)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Board of admission of electors; membership.

(Ord. of 8-27-68) 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-146 et seq.

Sec. 34-2. - Four-year terms for the registrars of voters. 
    In accordance with the powers granted by G.S. § 9-189a, commencing with the regular election to be held in 1974 and thereafter, the registrars of voters shall be elected for a term of four years from the first Wednesday following the first Monday of January succeeding their election. 
(Ord. No. 107, 10-2-72) 
Secs. 34-3-34-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VOTING DISTRICTS 

Sec. 34-36. - Established; enumerated; descriptions. 
(a)  Pursuant to section 2-3 of the town Charter and G.S. § 9-169a and further pursuant to the 2001 plan of districting for the state, two voting districts are established for the town, to be known as district 1 and district 2, for the purpose of voting for all town, state and national officials and measures required to be voted upon by ballot at elections and town meetings. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section the dividing line between district 1 and district 2 shall be established by a line beginning at the point of intersection of the Coventry-Andover town boundary with the centerline of Skinner Hill Road at or near the northeasterly corner of the Town of Andover; thence running along Skinner Hill Road in a northeasterly direction to the intersection of South Street; thence continuing along South Street in a southeasterly direction to the intersection of Seagraves Road; thence continuing along Seagraves Road in a northwesterly direction to the intersection of Talcott Hill Road; thence continuing along Talcott Hill Road in a northeasterly direction to the intersection of Main Street, also known as Route 31; thence continuing along Main Street, also known as Route 31, in a southeasterly direction to the intersection of Sam Green Road; thence continuing along Sam Green Road in a northeasterly direction to the intersection of Richmond Road; thence continuing along Richmond Road in a northwesterly direction to the intersection of Boston Turnpike, also known as Route 44; thence continuing along Boston Turnpike, also known as Route 44, in an easterly direction to Brigham Tavern Brock; thence continuing along Brigham Tavern Brook in an easterly direction to the west bank of the Willimantic River. 
(c)  The first district shall comprise all that portion of the town lying southeast of the previously described line and shall be called district 1. 
(d)  The second district shall comprise all that portion of the town lying northwest of the previously described line and shall be called district 2. 
(e)  The dividing line between the two districts, as described in subsection (a), shall run along the centerline of all roads mentioned in that subsection and along the centerline of Brigham Tavern Brook. 
(Ord. No. 179, 2-3-92; Ord. No. 213, § 1, 3-18-02)

Footnotes:
