ARTICLE III. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-146 et seq. 

Sec. 78-71. - Adoption of state enabling legislation. 
    The town accepts and adopts the state enabling legislation on zoning, covered by chapter 124 of the general statutes (G.S. § 8-1 et seq.), and municipal planning commission covered by chapter 126 of general statutes (G.S. § 8-18 et seq.). 
(Res. of 6-4-51) 
Sec. 78-72. - Zoning commission empowered to act as planning commission. 
    In accordance with G.S. § 8-4a, the members of the town zoning commission are empowered to act as the town planning commission. 
(Res. of 6-4-51) 
Sec. 78-73. - Right to farm-Preamble. 
    The CT General Statutes Section 19a-341 of the State of Connecticut has declared that "no agricultural or farming operation, place, establishment or facility, or any of its appurtenances, or the operation thereof, shall be deemed to constitute a nuisance" provided the operation is following generally accepted agricultural practices. Generally accepted agricultural practices are determined by the Commissioner of Agriculture. 
    Several towns in CT have recently passed local Right-to-Farm(RTF) Ordinances. Some of these towns include: Brooklyn, Canterbury, Colchester, Columbia, Eastford, Granby, Glastonbury, Franklin, Hampton, Lebanon, Shelton, Suffield, Sprague, Thompson, and Woodstock. A local RTF ordinance reinforces this State Statute by emphasizing that a municipality supports local farms and farm businesses and views agriculture as a valued activity in the town. They are particularly useful where new residential and commercial development occurs adjacent to active farms. While new residences may be drawn by the charm of the rural landscape, they soon realize that farm operations create dust, odors and noise. In reaction to these perceived nuisances, non-farm neighbors may lodge complaints with the town or file lawsuits that can cripple or shut down farm operations. A local RTF ordinance may help new residences prepare for living in a farming community. 
    Additionally, local RTF ordinances are more likely to become a matter of public policy within a community and are more easily recognized and administered. Clearly stating what the town values may limit nuisance lawsuits or other farm and non-farm conflicts and establishes a vision for the town regarding agriculture that is less likely to change over time with the administration and personnel of the regulatory commissions. Knowing that the Town supports farms allows current farmers to reinvest in their farms knowing they have the support of the community despite future changes in town administration and many encourage new farmers into the community. 
    In conjunction with examining local zoning regulations, tax policies, and supporting "buy local" initiatives, a local RTF ordinance reaffirms a town's commitment to agriculture and identifies farming as an accepted and valued activity. 
(Ord. No. 240, 6-3-13) 
Sec. 78-74. - Purpose and intent. 
    Pursuant to the powers conferred upon by G.S. § 7-148(c)(7)(E), (8), and, (10)(A), and furtherance of the goals of G.S. § 19a-341, the town adopts this section to officially recognize the importance of protecting agriculture as a whole because of its importance to the preservation of the Town's rural quality of life. This section encourages the pursuit of agriculture, promotes agricultural-based economic opportunities, and protects farmland within the town by allowing agricultural uses and related activities to function with minimal conflict with abutters and town agencies. Coventry recognizes the importance of farming to its history/heritage, culture, scenic vistas, and wildlife. It also recognizes the value it brings to its tax base, and economic development through local food security and other agricultural products. 
(Ord. No. 240, § I, 6-3-13) 
Sec. 78-75. - Definitions. 
    The terms "agricultural" and "farming" shall have all those meanings set forth in G.S. § 1-1(q), as amended. 
(Ord. No. 240, § II, 6-3-13) 
Sec. 78-76. - Right to farm. 
    G.S. § 19a-341 notwithstanding, any general statute or municipal ordinance or regulation pertaining to nuisances to the contrary, no agricultural or farming operation, place, establishment or facility, or any of its appurtenances, or the operation thereof, shall be deemed to constitute a nuisance, either public or private, due to alleged objectionable: 
(1)  Odor from livestock, manure, fertilizer or feed, 
(2)  Noise from livestock, or farm equipment used in normal, generally acceptable farming procedures, 
(3)  Dust created during plowing or cultivation operations, 
(4)  Use of herbicides and pesticides, provided such use and method of their application conform to practices approved by the commissioner of energy and environmental protection, and/or where applicable, the commissioner of public health, or 
(5)  Water pollution from livestock or crop production activities, except the pollution of public or private drinking water supplies, provided such activities conform to acceptable management practices for pollution control approved by the commissioner of energy and environmental protection, and/or where applicable, the commissioner of public health; provided such agricultural or farming operation, place, establishment or facility has been in operation for one-year or more, and has not been substantially changed an such operation follows generally accepted agricultural practices. 
Inspection and approval of the agricultural or farming operation, place, establishment or facility by the commissioner of agriculture or his designee shall be prima facie evidence that such operation follows generally accepted agricultural practices. 
(Ord. No. 240, § III, 6-3-13) 
Sec. 78-77. - Willful or reckless misconduct not protected. 
    The provisions of this section shall not apply whenever a nuisance results from negligence or willful or reckless misconduct in the operation of any such agricultural or farming operation, place, establishment or facility, or any of its appurtenances. 
(Ord. No. 240, § IV, 6-3-13) 
Sec. 78-78. - Impact on zoning. 
    Nothing contained in this section shall restrict the power of the town planning and zoning commission under G.S. ch. 124. The commission is urged to adopt regulations consistent with this section, and to make the permanent preservation of farmland within this municipality, a criterion in its planning and policy decisions. 
(Ord. No. 240, § V, 6-3-13) 
Sec. 78-79. - Severability. 
    If any section, paragraph, subdivision, clause, or provision of this ordinance shall be adjudged invalid, such adjudication shall apply only to the section, paragraph, subdivision, clause or provision so adjudged, and the remainder of this ordinance shall be deemed valid and effective. 
(Ord. No. 240, § VI, 6-3-13) 
Secs. 78-80-78-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONSERVATION COMMISSION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-146 et seq. 

Sec. 78-111. - Continuation; purposes. 
    The existence of the conservation commission as established by ordinance passed at town meeting on January 30, 1967, shall continue and shall survive the repeal of that ordinance. The purposes of the conservation commission shall be the development and conservation of natural resources, including water resources, within the territorial limits of the town. 
(Ord. No. 196, § 2, 9-16-96) 
Sec. 78-112. - Appointments and terms. 
(a)  The conservation commission shall consist of seven electors of the town, not more than four of whom shall be members of the same political party. All members shall be appointed by the town council, who may also remove any member for cause and fill any vacancy. Each person who was serving as a member of the conservation commission immediately prior to the effective date of Ordinance No. 196 shall continue to serve as a member of the conservation commission pursuant to this article for the balance of the term originally assigned to that member upon his appointment. 
(b)  Upon the expiration of the term of appointment of any member serving on the conservation commission as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, subsequent appointments shall be for a term of four years commencing on January 1. 
(Ord. No. 196, § 3, 9-16-96) 
Sec. 78-113. - Organization; recordkeeping; annual report. 
    The members of the conservation commission shall choose a chairperson, vice-chairperson, secretary and treasurer annually from its members. Nothing in this article shall affect the official status of any member serving as an officer of the conservation commission as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived. The conservation commission shall keep records of its meetings and activities and shall make an annual report to the town council. 
(Ord. No. 196, § 3, 9-16-96) 
Sec. 78-114. - Liaison with state department of environmental protection. 
    The chairperson of the conservation commission shall act as a liaison member with the commissioner of the state department of environmental protection. 
(Ord. No. 196, § 4, 9-16-96) 
Sec. 78-115. - Powers and duties. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, the conservation commission shall have all of the powers and duties set forth in G.S. § 7-131a, as it may be amended. The conservation commission shall conduct research into the utilization and possible utilization of land areas of the town and may coordinate the activities of unofficial bodies organized for similar purposes. It may advertise, prepare and distribute books, maps, charts, plans and pamphlets as necessary for its purposes. It may inventory natural resources and formulate watershed management and drought management plans. Such plans shall be consistent with water supply management plans prepared pursuant to G.S. § 25-32d. The conservation commission shall keep an index of all open space areas, publicly or privately owned, including open marshlands, swamps and other wetlands, for the purpose of obtaining information on the proper use of such areas, and may recommend to the planning commission plans and programs for the development and use of such areas. It may make recommendations to zoning commissions, planning commissions, inland wetlands agencies, and other municipal agencies on proposed land use changes. The conservation commission may propose a greenways plan for inclusion in the plan of conservation and development of the town prepared pursuant to G.S. § 8-23. It may, with the approval of the town council and in accordance with the provisions of the town Charter, acquire land and easements in the name of the town and promulgate rules and regulations including, but not limited to, the establishment of reasonable charges for the use of land and easements, for any of its purposes as set out in this section. It may supervise and manage municipally owned open space or property upon delegation of such authority by the town council. It shall keep records of its meetings and activities. It may also index, monitor and manage the town's interest in conservation easement areas. Furthermore, it may work with property owners to advise them of pertinent regulations and assist in developing appropriate conservation management plans. The conservation commission may recommend to the town council the acceptance of gifts for any of its purposes and may administer the same for such purposes subject to the term of the gift. The conservation commission may exchange information with the commissioner of environmental protection. The conservation commission will be responsible for preparing for council review and, upon council approval, disseminate such educational materials on proper waste disposal and recycling practices and may recommend program modifications to the town council. 
(Ord. No. 196, § 5, 9-16-96) 
Secs. 78-116-78-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes:

Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-146 et seq. 

Sec. 78-151. - Established. 
    The town hereby establishes an economic development commission in accordance with G.S. § 7-136. Such a commission will be nonpartisan and will have nine members whose terms shall not exceed five years, and shall be fixed so that the terms of approximately one-fifth of the members shall expire each year. They shall be appointed by the town council. An annual appropriation not to exceed 1/20 of one percent of the last completed grand list of taxable property may be applied for from the town council to take care of the expenses of the economic development commission. 
(Res. of 5-14-58) 
Sec. 78-152. - Purpose. 
    The economic development commission established under this article is appointed for the promotion and development of the business and industrial resources of the town. 
(Res. of 5-14-58) 
Secs. 78-153-78-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - INLAND WETLANDS AGENCY[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-146 et seq. 

Sec. 78-186. - Established to execute state law provisions. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of G.S. § 22a-42, the town council hereby establishes a new agency to be known as the inland wetlands agency to carry out the provisions of G.S. §§ 22a-36-22a-45 inclusive. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 2, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 78-187. - Membership; terms. 
    Such inland wetlands agency shall have five regular members and two alternates. The regular members shall be appointed for staggered terms as follows: two for a three-year term, two for a two-year term and one for a one-year term. Subsequent appointments shall be made for three-year terms. The alternate member shall be appointed to staggered terms: one for two years and one for one year. Subsequent alternates shall be appointed to three-year terms. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 3, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 78-188. - Appointments. 
    Appointment to the inland wetlands agency shall be by vote of the town council. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 4, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 78-189. - Powers and duties. 
    The inland wetlands agency shall enforce the existing town regulations adopted by its predecessor agency in conformity with the regulations promulgated by the commissioner of environmental protection pursuant to such provisions of G.S. § 22a-39 as are necessary to protect the wetlands and watercourses within the territorial limits of the town, and shall have all powers granted by G.S. ch. 440 to amend, modify, enforce and promulgate new regulations as such agency deems necessary to protect the wetlands and watercourses within the town. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 5, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 78-190. - Sole agent for licensing of regulated activities provided for in state law. 
    The inland wetlands agency shall serve as the sole agent for licensing of regulated activities as provided for by G.S. § 22a-42(c), subject to section 78-192. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 6, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 78-191. - Aquifer protection. 
    The inland wetlands agency shall be the aquifer protection agency within the meaning of G.S. § 22a-354o, to protect the town aquifer protection area, and shall enforce regulations to protect such areas in compliance with regulations adopted by the commissioner of environmental protection. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 7, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 78-192. - Continuation of existing agency for limited purposes. 
    It is the intent of this article to allow the inland wetlands agency (the town planning and zoning commission), as it existed on July 6, 1993, to complete all applications pending before it as of the effective date of this ordinance. For that purpose and for the purpose of any appeals from decisions of the inland wetlands agency, as it existed on July 6, 1993, to the superior court the authority of that agency shall continue after the effective date of Ordinance No. 190 for those limited purposes. 
(Ord. No. 190, § 8, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 78-193. - Citation procedures and fines for inland wetlands and watercourses violations. 
(a)  The wetlands agent (wetlands enforcement officer) is authorized to issue citations for violations of the inland wetlands and watercourses regulations of the town, to the extent and in the manner provided by this section. Any such citation may be served either by hand delivery or by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the person named in such citation. If the person named in a citation sent by certified mail refuses to accept such mail, the citation may be sent by regular United States mail. The wetlands agent shall file and retain an original or certified copy of the citation. 
(b)  Citations may be issued only for the following types of inland wetlands and watercourses violations: failure to properly install or maintain any erosion or sedimentation controls (including, but not limited to, silt fence, hay bales, and anti-tracking pad) required either by the inland wetlands and watercourses regulations or the terms or conditions of any permit or approval issued pursuant to those regulations. 
(c)  The fine for the first such citation issued to any person with respect to any specific parcel of land shall be $250.00. The fine for the second or subsequent citations issued to any person with respect to any specific parcel of land shall be $500.00. All fines shall be made payable to the Treasurer of the Town of Coventry. 
(d)  Any person receiving such a citation shall be allowed a period of 30 days from his or her receipt of the citation to make an uncontested payment of the fine specified in the citation to the treasurer. If the citation has been sent by regular mail pursuant to the provisions of subsection (a), the day of receipt of the citation shall be deemed to be three business days after the day of mailing of the citation. 
(e)  If a person who has been issued a citation does not make uncontested payment of the fine specified in the citation to the treasurer within the time allowed under subsection (d), the wetlands agent shall send a notice to the person cited, informing such person: (1) of the allegations against him or her, the amount of the fines, and the imposition of the administrative fee set forth in subsection (f); (2) that the person cited may contest liability before a hearing officer appointed by the town manager, as provided in subsection (i), by delivering, in person or by mail, within ten days of the date of the notice, a written demand for a hearing; (3) that if the person cited does not demand such a hearing, an assessment and judgment shall be entered against him or her; and (4) that such judgment may issue without further notice. 
(f)  If the person who is sent notice pursuant to subsection (e) wishes to admit liability for any alleged violation, he or she may, without requesting a hearing, pay the full amount of the fine, together with an additional administrative fee of $25.00, either in person or by mail, to the wetlands agent. All fines and fees shall be made payable to the Treasurer of the Town of Coventry. Such payment shall be inadmissible in any proceeding, civil or criminal, to establish the conduct of such person or other person making the payment. Any person who does not deliver or mail written demand for a hearing within ten days of the date of the notice described in subsection (e) shall be deemed to have admitted liability, and the wetlands agent shall certify to the hearing officer that such person has failed to respond. The hearing officer shall thereupon enter and assess the fines and fees provided for by this section and shall follow the procedures set forth in subsection (h). 
(g)  Any person who requests a hearing shall be given written notice of the date, time and place for the hearing. Such hearing shall be held not less than 15 days nor more than 30 days from the date of the mailing of notice, provided the hearing officer shall grant upon good cause shown any reasonable request by any interested party for postponement or continuance. The presence of the wetlands agent shall be required at the hearing if requested by the person who was issued the citation. A person wishing to contest liability shall appear at the hearing and may present evidence in his or her behalf. The wetlands agent may present evidence on behalf of the municipality. If the person who received the citation fails to appear, the hearing officer may enter an assessment by default against him or her upon a finding of proper notice and liability under the applicable provisions of the inland wetlands and watercourses regulations. The hearing officer may accept written information by mail from the person who received the citation and may determine thereby that the appearance of such person is unnecessary. The hearing officer shall conduct the hearing in the order and from and with such methods of proof as he or she deems fair and appropriate. The rules regarding the admissibility of evidence shall not be strictly applied, but all testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation. The hearing officer shall announce his or her decision at the end of the hearing. If the hearing officer determines that the person who received the citation is not liable, the hearing officer shall dismiss the matter and enter that determination in writing accordingly. If the hearing officer determines that the person who received the citation is liable for the violation, the hearing officer shall forthwith enter and assess the fines against such person as provided by this section, including an additional hearing fee of $50.00. 
(h)  If such assessment is not paid on the date of its entry, the hearing officer shall send by first class mail a notice of the assessment to the person found liable and shall file, not less than 30 days nor more than 12 months after such mailing, a certified copy of the notice of assessment with the clerk of the Superior Court for Geographical Area No. 19 in Rockville, together with an entry fee of $8.00 or such other amount as may be required by state law. Further proceedings may then be held pursuant to the applicable provisions of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
(i)  The town manager shall appoint one or more citation hearing officers to conduct the hearings provided by this section. Neither the wetlands agent, the building inspector, nor any other employee of the town may be appointed as a hearing officer pursuant to this section. The rate of compensation of the hearing officer shall be determined by the town manager. 
(j)  No citation shall be issued pursuant to this section unless (1) the wetlands agent has provided notice of the violation to the person who would receive the citation; (2) the notice specifies a reasonable time for the violation to be corrected; and (3) the violation is not corrected within the time required. The hearing officer shall not uphold the issuance of any citation if he or she determines that the time provided for the violation to be corrected was unreasonable under all of the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 208, §§ 1-10, 4-17-00) 
Chapter 82 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; waste disposal in cemeteries, § 22-87; environment, ch. 38; health and sanitation, ch. 50; littering in town parks and beaches, § 70-75; utilities, ch. 102. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 82-1-82-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LITTER 

Sec. 82-31. - Short title of article. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Town of Coventry Antilitter Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 103, § 1, 3-1-71) 
Sec. 82-32. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized private receptacle means a litter storage and collection receptacle as may from time to time be required, defined and authorized by the regulations of the building inspector of the town. 
    Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Litter means garbage, refuse, and rubbish and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as prohibited in this article, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
    Park means a park, reservation, playground, recreation center or any other public area in the town, owned or used by the town and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Private premises means any dwelling, house, building or other structure, designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways, and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 2, 3-1-71) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-33. - In public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the town except in public receptacles, in authorized private receptacles for collection or in official town dumps. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 3, 3-1-71) 
Sec. 82-34. - Placement in receptacles to prevent scattering. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place, or upon private property. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 4, 3-1-71) 
Sec. 82-35. - Sweeping into gutters. 
    No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or public place within the town the accumulation of litter from any building or lot, or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 5, 3-1-71) 
Sec. 82-36. - Merchant's duty to keep sidewalks free. 
    No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the town the accumulation of litter from any building or lot, or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying places of business within the town shall keep the sidewalk in front of their business premises free of litter. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 6, 3-1-71) 
Sec. 82-37. - Thrown by persons in vehicles. 
    No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the town, or upon private property. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 7, 3-1-71) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 98. 
Sec. 82-38. - Truck loads causing. 
    No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the town unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. No person shall drive or move any vehicle or truck within the town, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky substance, litter or foreign matter of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 8, 3-1-71) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. 
Sec. 82-39. - In parks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the town except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for the presence and properly disposed of elsewhere, as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 9, 3-1-71) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 70. 
Sec. 82-40. - In lakes and fountains. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or any other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the town. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 10, 3-1-71) 
Sec. 82-41. - Throwing, depositing on occupied private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the town, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place, or upon any private property. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 11, 3-1-71) 
Sec. 82-42. - Owner to maintain premises free from. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 12, 3-1-71) 
Sec. 82-43. - Clearing from open private property by town. 
(a)  Notice to remove. The building inspector is hereby authorized and empowered to notify the owner of any open or vacant private property within the town, or the agent of such owner, to properly dispose of litter located on such owner's property which is dangerous to public health, safety or welfare. Such notice shall be by certified mail, addressed to such owner or his agent at his last known address. 
(b)  Appeal from notice. 
(1)  The owner or agent so notified shall have the right to appeal from such notice and order within two days after receipt of such notice, to the board of health of the town. 
(2)  Upon such appeal the board of health shall forthwith hold a hearing at such time and place as it shall determine. A majority of such board of health shall constitute a quorum for such hearing. Such owner or agent may act before such board either by himself or by counsel. The decision of such board shall be final. 
(3)  If such owner or agent does not appeal from such order within the time permitted, or in the event such board sustains the order of the building inspector, then the provisions of subsections (c), (d), (e) and (f) of this section and the penalties provided in section 82-44 shall apply. 
(c)  Action upon noncompliance. Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner or agent so notified to properly dispose of litter dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare within three days after receipt of written notice provided for in subsection (a) of this section, or within three days after the date of such notice if the notice is returned to the town post office department because of its inability to make delivery thereof, provided the notice was properly addressed to the last known address of such owner or agent, the town manager is hereby authorized and empowered to pay for the disposing of such litter or to order its disposal by the town. 
(d)  Charge for abatement included in tax bill. When the town has effected the removal of such dangerous litter or has paid for its removal, the actual cost thereof, plus accrued interest at the rate of six percent per annum from the date of the completion of the work, if not paid by such owner prior thereto, shall be charged to the owner of such property on the next regular tax bill forwarded to such owner by the town. Such charge shall be due and payable by the owner at the time of payment of such bill. 
(e)  Recorded statement constitutes a lien. Where the full amount due the town is not paid by such owner within 30 days after the disposal of such litter, as provided for in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, then, and in that case, the town manager shall cause to be recorded in the town clerk's office a sworn statement showing the cost and expense incurred for the work, the date the work was done and the location of the property on which such work was done. The recording of such sworn statement shall constitute a lien and privilege on the property, and shall remain in full force and effect for the amount due in principal and interest, plus costs of court, if any, for collection, until final payment has been made. Such costs and expenses shall be collected in the manner fixed by law for the collection of taxes and, further, shall be subject to a delinquent penalty of one-half of one percent per month if such costs and expenses are not paid in full on or before the date the tax bill upon which such charge appears becomes delinquent. Sworn statements recorded in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be prima facie evidence that all legal formalities have been complied with, and that the work has been done properly and satisfactorily, and shall be full notice to every person concerned that the amount of the statement, plus interest, constitutes a charge against the property designated or described in the statement that the same is due and collectible as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 13, 3-1-71) 
Sec. 82-44. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined in an amount not exceeding $25.00 per day. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 14, 3-1-71) 
Secs. 82-45-82-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SOLID WASTE AND MUNICIPAL RESOURCE RECOVERY AUTHORITY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, committees, commissions, § 2-146 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-76. - Short title of article. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Solid Waste/Municipal Resource Recovery Authority Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 189, § 1, 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-77. - Purpose of article. 
    This article is adopted to establish a municipal resource recovery authority in the town pursuant to chapters 103b, 446d and 446e of the Connecticut General Statutes (G.S. §§ 7-273aa-7-273pp, 22a-207-22a-256ee, 22a-257-22a-285k) and to update and consolidate the town's landfill use and recycling ordinance to comply with the state's mandatory recycling law. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 2, 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-78. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bulky waste means large, nonputrescible items such as discarded appliances and furniture, stumps and bushes, construction debris and demolition waste and/or land clearing debris including, but not limited to, brick, mortar, wood and glass. 
    Collection means the act of collecting solid waste or recyclables at the place of waste generation by an approved, licensed solid waste collector and is distinguished from removal. 
    Collection vehicle or equipment means any vehicle or equipment used in the collection of residential refuse, commercial solid waste or recyclables. 
    Commercial container means each container or bin of one cubic yard or more owned by a solid waste collector and placed for use at a business, commercial location, residence, apartment building or construction site. Each commercial container shall be identified with the name and telephone number of the solid waste collector servicing the container or bin. 
    Corrugated cardboard means cardboard which has been processed to have forms or shapes like wrinkles or folds or into alternating ridges and grooves and is placed between two flat surfaces for the sake of strength and which is commonly used to form cartons. 
    Disposal area means an area or location used for the disposal of solid waste designated as such by the municipal resource recovery authority. 
    Dry-cell battery means any device used for generating electric current through a chemical reaction including, but not limited to, nickel-cadmium batteries, carbon batteries and alkaline batteries. 
    Garbage means all kitchen and table food waste and animal or vegetable waste that attends or results from the storage, preparation, cooking or handling of foodstuffs. 
    Glass containers means jars and bottles made of silica, soda ash and limestone being transparent, translucent and breakable. Specifically excluded are plastics, window glass or panes, glass bulbs, ceramics and all other glass. 
    Health officer means the duly appointed director of health of the town or designated agent. 
    Household cardboard means a stiff, moderately thick paperboard used in packaging products for household consumption. 
    Magazines means all magazines or periodicals printed on glossy stock or paper of heavier quality than that commonly recognized as newsprint. 
    Metal food and beverage containers means tin, bimetal, steel or aluminum cans that once contained food or beverages for humans or animals. 
    Nuisance means any condition which, in the judgment of the town director of health or designated agent, constitutes or could constitute a threat to the public health including, but not limited to, those conditions specifically listed in section 19-13-B1 of the state public health code. 
    Office paper means white, high grade paper generally used in offices that is of high quality and does not have a glossy finish including, but not limited to, photocopy paper, bond, ledger, tab cards, letterhead and white computer paper. 
    Processing facilities means a place or facility where solid waste materials are sorted, crushed, cleaned or otherwise processed prior to final disposal or recovery. 
    Recyclable materials means materials which have been so designated by the municipal resource recovery authority. These will include, but not be limited to, those materials designated as recyclable under the Connecticut General Statutes, as amended, and the regulations of the state department of environmental protection, as amended, prior to or at the time designated by those statutes and/or regulations. 
    Recycling means the reuse of recovered resources through the process of sorting, cleaning, treating and reconstituting materials otherwise destined for disposal. 
    Recycling bin means any box or container designated as a recycling container by the municipal resource recovery authority. 
    Refuse means both garbage and rubbish. 
    Refuse container means any rodentproof heavy plastic or metal box, can, barrel, bin or similar type container used for the accumulation of refuse. 
    Removal means the act of taking solid wastes from the place of waste generation either by a licensed solid waste collector or by a person in control of the premises. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible waste including, but not limited to, ashes, paper, tinware, rubber, wood, glass, rags, crockery, plastics, rubber byproducts or litter, or other unusable or discarded material resulting from normal community or business activities, or materials which by their presence may injuriously affect the health, safety and comfort of persons or may depreciate property values in its vicinity, or both; provided, however, that the term "rubbish" shall not include bulky waste and materials generated by a person and held by that person to be salvaged. 
    Scrap metal means used or discarded items which consist predominantly of ferrous metals, aluminum, brass, copper, lead, chromium, tin, nickel or alloys thereof including, but not limited to, discarded home and industrial appliances. 
    Solid waste means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid and semisolid wastes, such as refuse, garbage, rubbish, bulky wastes, paper, ashes, industrial waste, demolition and construction wastes, abandoned vehicles and parts thereof, discarded home and industrial appliances, manure, vegetable or animal solid and semisolid wastes; and other discarded solid and semisolid wastes, including liquid waste disposed of in conjunction with solid wastes at solid waste transfer/processing stations or disposal sites, but excluding sewage collected and treated in a municipal or a regional system; hazardous waste; or radioactive waste. 
    Solid waste collector means a person who has been issued a license pursuant to this article by the town to collect and haul refuse or recyclable material from residential, business, commercial or other establishments for hire within the town. 
    Storage battery means batteries used in motor vehicles, airplanes, boats, recreational vehicles, tractors and like applications, or other lead-acid batteries. 
    Transfer station means a place or facility used to receive garbage or rubbish from private vehicles and/or collection vehicles from which this garbage/rubbish is subsequently hauled to a disposal area in large vehicles or trailers. 
    Waste oil means crank case oil that has been utilized in internal combustion engines. 
    Yard waste means the brush, boughs and foliage of trees and other plants, including grass clippings and leaves. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 6, 6-10-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-79. - Storage of solid waste and recyclable materials. 
(a)  All persons occupying or maintaining any premises within the town where refuse and recyclable materials are created, produced or accumulated shall maintain sufficient refuse or recycling containers for receiving and holding all refuse and recyclable materials produced, created or accumulated on such premises. Where a solid waste collector furnishes such containers, he shall be responsible for maintaining the containers in good condition unless this responsibility has been assumed by the person occupying or maintaining the premises under the terms or conditions of the use. 
(b)  No person shall accumulate, store or require the storage or handling of solid waste or recyclable materials in such a manner so as to promote the propagation, harborage or attraction of vectors or so as to create a nuisance or hazard to public travel, health or safety. 
(c)  The owner of solid wastes or recyclable material generated on any property shall cause the same to be removed by an authorized solid waste collector at frequencies sufficient to prevent the occurrence of a nuisance. 
(d)  Except for commercial containers, refuse/recycling containers maintained as provided in this section shall be located on the property or premises of the person producing such refuse in such areas so as not to be visible from the street, sidewalk or public place except after 5:00 p.m. the day before the pickup and before 8:00 p.m. on the day of the pickup. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 8, 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-80. - Disposal of refuse. 
(a)  All refuse generated, produced, accumulated or collected within the town shall be disposed of only in a manner as may be designated by the municipal resource recovery authority. The municipal resource recovery authority is hereby authorized to make such regulations as may be necessary for the public convenience and necessity. Such regulations may differentiate between types of waste materials, persons, establishments (residential or commercial) and solid waste collectors as may be necessary in order to provide for recycling and the cost effective and efficient collection and disposal of refuse. 
(b)  The use of the town collection, processing or disposal facilities shall be restricted to licensed solid waste collectors, residents of the town and businesses within the town. 
(c)  Refuse generated outside the town will not be accepted at any town disposal facility without approval of the town council. No person shall engage in any scavenging, salvaging or recycling activities at any town solid waste facility without the written permission of the municipal resource recovery authority. 
(d)  The municipal resource recovery authority may, by resolution, establish regulations and fees for the collection of refuse. Such regulations may include, but are not limited to, the types of solid waste which may be collected, the hours of operation, permitted salvaging or recycling operations and any other regulations necessary. 
(e)  Refuse generated from outside of the town shall not be mixed with local refuse prior to delivery to an authorized disposal facility. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 9, 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-81. - Ownership of refuse. 
    All refuse and other solid waste materials, including materials for recycling, upon being removed from the premises where produced or accumulated, shall become the property of the solid waste collector. Upon being deposited in a designated transfer, processing or disposal facility, such materials shall forthwith become the property of the owner of such facility. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 10, 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-82. - Recycling. 
    All persons or establishments generating solid wastes and/or recyclable materials in the town must separate the recyclable materials from the nonrecyclable materials in accordance with the regulations established by the municipal resource recovery authority. Designated, unsoiled recyclable materials shall not be mixed with other refuse, nor shall they be accepted unless they are properly separated and deposited in a container designated for recyclable materials. Failure to separate designated materials for recycling is a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 11, 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-83. - Enforcement of article. 
(a)  The municipal resource recovery authority acting by and through the town manager, health officer, the department of public works and their duly authorized representatives is hereby specifically required to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate any provision of this article or any provision of any regulation adopted by resolution of the municipal resource recovery authority pursuant to the authority granted by this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $90.00. Each failure to comply and each continuing day of violation shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 13, 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-84. - Collection of fees. 
    The municipal resource recovery authority shall have the authority to establish reasonable fees to cover the town's expenses for solid waste management. Fees for pickup and disposal shall be based on an economic projection of the costs of operation. Fees for licenses or special procedures shall be based on estimates of administrative costs. Prior to establishing or modifying any fees, the municipal resource recovery authority shall hold a public hearing with at least ten days' legal notice. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 14, 6-10-93) 
Secs. 82-85-82-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MUNICIPAL RESOURCE RECOVERY AUTHORITY 

Sec. 82-106. - Creation and designation. 
    Pursuant to G.S. § 7-273aa(b), the municipal resource recovery authority is hereby created for the regulation and control of solid wastes in the town. The town council is hereby designated as the municipal authority. The authority is so created as a municipal resource recovery authority under G.S. §§ 7-273aa-7-273oo inclusive, and shall have all of the powers provided under such section and under chapters 446d and 446e (G.S. §§ 22a-207-22a-256ee and 22a-257-22a-285k) of such statutes. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 3, 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-107. - Offices. 
    The municipal resource recovery authority shall have its principal office at the Coventry Town Hall, 1712 Main Street, Coventry, CT 06238. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 4, 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-108. - Authority's scope. 
    The municipal resource recovery authority shall have control over the total solid waste stream within the town, including control over the operation of any town-owned solid waste landfill, recycling processing facility, sludge disposal area or any like facilities. All policies, permits, contracts and agreements concerning refuse collection, landfill operation, trash dumping and recycling shall be subject to municipal resource recovery authority regulation, approval and acceptance. The municipal resource recovery authority is authorized to employ or make contracts with individual persons or corporations for the separation, recovery, collection, removal, storage, transport or disposition of garbage, rubbish and other refuse, including recyclables. The municipal resource recovery authority is further empowered to charge fees and to issue bills or collect fees to/from recipients of such services, and to take appropriate action to collect such fees as provided for in section 82-84. The municipal resource recovery authority may, by resolution, establish regulations, policies and fees for the use of town processing or recycling facilities, disposal areas and for all refuse and recycling pickup within the town. Such regulations may include, but are not limited to, the types of materials which are to be collected, hauled and deposited at any facility; the days, place and hours of refuse or recycling pickup and facility operation; fees to be charged at any facility or for any town authorized collection service, requirements and fees for collector permits; and the designation of recycling or refuse collection systems with the town by type of establishment, frequency of collection, level of service and cost. The municipal resource recovery authority shall also be responsible for enforcing this article and its adopted regulations as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 5, 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-109. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The municipal resource recovery authority is authorized to adopt regulations designating materials that must be recycled and separated from other refuse in the town. Such designations shall be included, but are not limited to, those items required to be recycled by state statutes or the state department of environmental protection regulations. 
(b)  The municipal resource recovery authority shall also be authorized to adopt regulations designating how and when such recyclable materials shall be recycled including, but not limited to, the days and times of collection, manner of collection, preparation and separation of such materials prior to collection. 
(c)  The municipal resource recovery authority may also by regulation adopt rules and requirements for recycling for different types of establishments differentiating between single-family residential, multifamily residential (including condominiums) and commercial or business establishments. Such rules may designate the responsibilities of each type of establishment in complying with the town's recycling ordinance and regulations. 
(d)  The municipal resource recovery authority is specifically directed and empowered to enforce all provisions of this article and the provisions of any regulations adopted by the municipal resource recovery authority pursuant to this article as provided for in section 82-108. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 11, 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-110. - Collection and transport. 
    Refuse and recyclable materials hauled by any person over any road in the town shall be securely tied or covered during the hauling thereof. No person shall allow any refuse or recyclable to leak, spill, blow off or drop from any vehicle on any road. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(a), 6-10-93) 
Secs. 82-111-82-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VEHICLE PERMIT 

Sec. 82-131. - Intent of division; exemptions. 
    It is the intent of this division to prohibit hauling refuse or recyclable materials for hire without first receiving a license pursuant to this article. No person shall collect, haul or transport refuse or recyclable materials on any public highway within the town without first making application to the town and receiving a solid waste collector's permit. The provisions of this section shall not apply to persons hauling household refuse from their own residences; nor to farming or agricultural operations; nor to municipalities or public agencies; nor to industrial, commercial or business establishments; nor to building contractors; nor to any of those hauling their own refuse generated by themselves. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(d), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-132. - Required; exception. 
    No person shall use any vehicle for collecting, hauling or transporting refuse or recyclable materials on any public road within the town without first obtaining a vehicle permit from the town; provided, however, that no person exempted from obtaining a collector's permit pursuant to section 82-131 shall be required to obtain a vehicle permit. It is the intent of this division to prohibit any person from hauling garbage, rubbish, debris, refuse and recyclable materials for hire over town roads without obtaining a vehicle permit pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(b), (e), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-133. - Fees; application; assignment and display generally. 
    The municipal resource recovery authority may, by resolution, set fees for vehicle permits for each vehicle proposed to be used to haul refuse or recyclable materials for hire or dispose of refuse or recyclable materials at any town-designated transfer, processing or disposal facility. Each person shall file with the town, in writing, on a form furnished and approved by the town, such information as the public works department deem necessary in the issuing of a permit for each vehicle proposed to be used. The town shall assign a permit number to each truck upon approval of the application. The applicant shall affix such permit to each truck in the manner prescribed by the town in the locations on such truck as may be prescribed by the town. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(c), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-134. - Contents of application. 
    Applicants for a new or renewed solid waste collector's permit pursuant to this article, or an existing licensee seeking to modify his permit shall file with the town a verified application in writing, on a form furnished and approved by the town, which shall have the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of the applicant. 
(2)  Permanent home and business address and full local address of the applicant. 
(3)  Trade and firm name. 
(4)  If a joint venture, a partnership or limited partnership, the names of all partners, their percentage of participation and the permanent addresses of all the stockholders and the officers, and the percentage participation of each. 
(5)  The names/locations of the designated transfer station, processing facility or disposal area that the applicant will utilize for the disposal of all refuse collected and transported by him. Such name/location shall be acceptable to the town, and in conformance with section 82-108. 
(6)  The number of vehicles owned or controlled by the applicant suitable for the collection and transportation of refuse or recyclable materials, including license numbers and the volume in cubic yards of each. 
(7)  A statement that his vehicles and equipment conform to all applicable provisions of this article. 
(8)  The locations where the applicant's equipment is garaged and may be inspected by the town. 
(9)  A map of each proposed collection route shown to a size and scale suitable to the town, together with a listing of names of the town roads on each route, the number of residential and commercial customers on each route and the day of the week regular collection service will be provided on that route. Such route listings are to be tallied to give the total number of residential and commercial customers proposed to be served accurately and up to the date of the application submitted. 
(10)  The rate or rate schedule the applicant proposes to charge residential or commercial customers in the town. 
(11)  A detailed estimate of the volume of refuse expected to be collected and transported to a designated town disposal area for a period of one year. 
(12)  The applicant's relevant municipal solid waste collection experience. 
(13)  Such other information as the town shall require. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(f), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-135. - Filing fees. 
    All applications shall be accompanied by a filing fee for each application for the issuance of a new permit, the renewal of an existing permit or the modification of an existing permit. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(g), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-136. - Investigation and recommendation by department of public works to manager. 
    The department of public works shall conduct such investigation of each application as it shall deem necessary so as to be able to recommend to the town manager whether such application should be granted in whole, in part or denied. Such recommendation shall include the department of public works findings based on the information contained in the application submitted; the applicant's relevant municipal solid waste collection experience concerning the ability of the applicant to properly perform the service proposed and to conform to the provisions of this article; and the rules and regulations of the town and the department of public works' conclusion as to whether the proposed service is or will be required by the present or future public convenience and necessity. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(h), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-137. - Approval or conditional approval; issuance; denial. 
    Upon receipt of the recommendation of the department of public works, the town manager may approve, either in whole or in part, or conditionally approve the application upon finding that: 
(1)  The applicant is able to properly perform the services proposed and to conform to the requirements of this article and the rules and regulations of the town. 
(2)  The proposed service is or will be required by the present and future public convenience and necessity. 
Upon approval or conditional approval, the department of public works shall issue the appropriate permit. If either required finding is not made, the application shall be denied. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(i), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-138. - Duration; expiration date of existing permits. 
    All collection permits issued under this article shall be effective for one year from the date of issuance unless otherwise provided or revoked or suspended. All collectors must apply for permits as provided for in this division or be in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(j), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-139. - Transfer; consent required. 
    No permit granted pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be sold, transferred, leased, assigned, mortgaged, pledged, hypothecated, or otherwise encumbered or disposed of, in whole or part, directly or indirectly, whether voluntarily or by operation of law or through any stock transfer, transfer in trust, change in control, consolidation or merger, without the prior written consent of the town manager. The town manager may grant or deny such a request or may require that the proposed transferee apply for its own license and may impose such conditions as he may deem to be in the public interest. Any disposition made without such consent shall constitute good cause for revocation of the affected permit. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(k), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-140. - Suspension, cancellation or revocation; conditions causing. 
    Any permit issued under the provision of this article may be suspended, cancelled or revoked on ten days' written notice mailed to the last business address of the permittee and shall be transmitted by certified mail, return receipt requested, upon the following: 
(1)  Any permittee fails or refuses to comply with the provisions of this article. Any regulations adopted by the municipal resource recovery authority pursuant to this article or the applicable rules and regulations of the town. 
(2)  The permit is not exercised for any continuous 30-day period. 
(3)  The permittee has assigned, either voluntarily or by operation of law, any permit issued under this article without the prior written approval of the town manager. 
(4)  If the department of public works and/or director of health finds that the vehicles used or proposed to be used by the permittee for the collection and transportation of refuse are insufficient, unfit, violate the provisions of this article, violate state health code requirements or violate the town regulations adopted in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(l), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-141. - Recordkeeping by permittees. 
    All permittees under the provisions of this article shall keep and maintain such records as the town manager may require to ascertain the extent of compliance with this article and shall make the financial or business records of the permittees operation available for inspection by the town manager, if so requested. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(m), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-142. - Equipment required to be carried on vehicles of permittees. 
    Each vehicle hauling refuse in the town under a permit shall carry at least a shovel, broom and appropriate type of fire extinguisher. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(n), 6-10-93) 
Sec. 82-143. - Permittees to arrange equipment inspections. 
    Permittees shall arrange to have their equipment inspected in July of each year for certification by the department of public works that their equipment conforms to the regulations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 189, § 12(o), 6-10-93) 
Secs. 82-144-82-159. - Reserved.

Chapter 86 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
